translated: Sutra of the Wise and the Foolish, Scroll 28
Translated by the Yao Qin Dynasty monk Zhu Fonian from Liangzhou
Chapter 32: The Mind and Thoughts, Chapter on the Mind and Thoughts
Light and difficult to guard, dwelling in desire, subduing the mind is good,
subduing it brings peace.

As for light and difficult to guard, the reason the TathÄgata, the World-Honored One, appears in the world is precisely to subdue people's minds and remove impure and evil conduct. Like those who practice, they always contemplate and discuss the mind, saying that the mind attracts many calamities and causes people to enter the paths of hell, hungry ghosts, and animals. Therefore, it is said, light and difficult to guard.

As for dwelling in desire, those practitioners observe that the arising of illness all has causes and conditions. Investigating the origin of desire, it lies in the mind and thoughts. It is like thieves relying on dangers to rob. If there were no dangers, there would be no way for troubles to arise.
Desire is also like this. The mind is a den and a cave. It turns and runs around, forming calamities and troubles. Therefore, it is said, Dwelling in desire.

Subduing the mind is good. With subduing, there is peace. People can subdue their minds and not record their lifespan. Wherever they go, they are respected by others. After death, their defilements are exhausted, their minds are liberated, and they attain complete nirvana. Therefore, it is said, Subduing the mind is good. With subduing, there is peace.
Like a fish on dry land, separated from the deep abyss,
The mind and consciousness are extremely agitated, and the demon hordes run around.

Like a fish on dry land, separated from the deep abyss is like that fish losing the abyss and rolling on the ground. The mind and thoughts are troubled and not free. Therefore, it is said, Like a fish on dry land, separated from the deep abyss.

The mind and consciousness are extremely agitated, and the hordes of demons run about, just like fish on the shore jumping and writhing, unable to be at ease. The mind is also like this, running towards various afflictions and unable to stop itself, then it is taken advantage of by various deviant forces.
Therefore it is said, The mind and consciousness are extremely agitated, and the hordes of demons run about.
The mind runs not in one place, just like the light of the sun,
The wise one can control it, like a hook stopping a bad elephant.

The mind runs to many places, just like the light of the sun. When the sunlight first appears, it illuminates the four directions, reaching everywhere. The mind is also like this, rushing towards forms, sounds, smells, tastes, and tactile objects, unable to control itself and prevent it from flowing and running. It is like a vicious elephant that is difficult to tame. Only when it is restrained by a hook can it be controlled. Therefore, it is said, The mind runs to many places, just like the light of the sun. Only the wise can control it, like a hook stopping a vicious elephant.
I now discuss this mind, which is unyielding and invisible.
I now wish to instruct and admonish, so be careful not to give rise to faults.
As for I now discuss this mind, which is unyielding and invisible, the practitioner focuses his mind and concentrates on the present, using various skillful means to admonish and reproach his mind:

Because of your mind, for countless eons you have gone through birth and death, abandoning one body and receiving another, beyond measure or record, sometimes in the three evil paths and eight difficult situations, sometimes in the heavens and among humans, coming and going;
Now that I have encountered the Buddha's holy Dharma as a human, I should abandon my original thoughts of attachment.
Having admonished the mind with countless skillful means, he further told the mind:
You are now fragile and cannot be relied upon. In this life, you should end all bonds of love.
Therefore it is said, I now discuss this mind, which is not solid and cannot be seen. I now wish to instruct and admonish it, so that no flaws arise.
Do not let your mind wander, indulging in carelessness,
I will now restrain you, like controlling a wild and unruly elephant.

Do not let your mind wander, indulging in carelessness. The mind is an unstable thing, attached to forms, sounds, smells, tastes, and tactile objects, like a monkey greedy for fruits, abandoning one to take another, the mind is not focused, and thus it gives rise to myriad thoughts and creates various troubles, unable to let go. Therefore it is said, Do not let your mind wander, indulging in carelessness.

I will now restrain you, like controlling a rampaging elephant. I will use the contemplation of impurity to restrain this mind and prevent it from running wild, like controlling a rampaging elephant and not letting it be careless. Therefore it is said, I will now restrain you, like controlling a rampaging elephant.
Birth and death are immeasurable, coming and going without end,
Those who seek a dwelling repeatedly receive a womb.

As for birth and death are immeasurable, coming and going without end, people experience birth and death for countless eons, passing through the realms of hell, animals, and hungry ghosts, undergoing suffering that is extremely difficult to calculate. Therefore, it is said, birth and death are immeasurable, coming and going without end.

As for those who seek a dwelling repeatedly receive a womb, they do not extinguish the traces of their actions, coming and going without rest, bound by attachment to fat and white, repeatedly receiving a womb. Therefore, it is said, those who seek a dwelling repeatedly receive a womb.
Observing this dwelling, one does not build a house again. The beams and planks are already decayed,
and the terraces and pavilions are destroyed.
Observing this dwelling means that it is fragile and not solid, bound to decay and perish, and subject to the law of destruction. Even Mount Sumeru and the great ocean will eventually melt away.
As for not building a house again, the reason is this:
Knowing the root causes and origins of illness, one no longer accepts form and creates the five aggregates' abode. Therefore, it is said, By observing this house, one does not build a dwelling again.
The beams and terraces are already destroyed, and the platforms and pavilions are toppled. The reason for discussing this is to discuss the original source of afflictions;

When the body perishes and the four elements disperse, myriad things do not last long. This is discussing the person who has attained the Way, who abandons the body and departs the spirit, calmly and serenely empty, with the limbs and form each returning to its origin, earth returning to earth, water to water, fire to fire, and wind to wind. The spirit departs and becomes non-active, no longer fearing to come again and accept a body. Therefore, it is said, The beams and terraces are already destroyed, and the platforms and pavilions are toppled.
The mind has already departed from activities, and in the middle, it has ceased. The mind is fickle,
difficult to hold and difficult to guard.

As for the mind has already departed from action, it refers to the fact that among the many bonds of practitioners, the reason why the multitude is submerged in birth and death is all due to creating actions that lead to these calamities. The sages descend into the world and diligently cultivate themselves, cutting off the root of all actions and preventing them from arising again. Therefore, it is said that the mind has already departed from action.
As for already extinguished in the middle, the dharmas of the three times are eternally exhausted without remainder. Therefore, it is said that it is already extinguished in the middle.
As for the mind being light and agitated, it is as explained in the Buddha's sutras:

I now explain that the mind is originally light, agitated, and swift. In a single day and night, there are 99,999,900,000 thoughts, with each thought having different concepts and creating actions that are not the same.
Therefore, it is said that the mind is light and agitated.

Difficult to uphold and difficult to guard means that in the moment of giving rise to the mind, one creates wholesome or unwholesome actions. The mind of wholesome thoughts immediately reaches without obstruction, and the mind of unwholesome thoughts is like an echo responding to sound. Wanting to guard it is impossible.

It is like the category of vicious beasts, tigers, wolves, snakes, vipers, and scorpions. Wanting to protect their minds and prevent them from doing evil is also something that has not been heard before.
Therefore, it is said, Difficult to uphold and difficult to guard.
The wise are able to correct themselves, just as a craftsman straightens an arrow,
If there is anger, they know there is anger, if there is anger, they know there is anger.

The wise can correct themselves, just as a craftsman straightens an arrow. When a person practices, they first correct their form, always knowing the Dharma of suffering, emptiness, non-self, and the six contemplations to admonish their body and prevent it from being crooked, just as a skilled craftsman can skillfully straighten an arrow, making it straight and without knots, capable of defeating the enemy without difficulty. Therefore it is said, The wise can correct themselves, just as a craftsman straightens an arrow.

If there is anger, then know there is anger. If there is anger, know there is anger. Hatred arises from this, but there has never been one who has ended hatred by hatred. One must end hatred, extinguish hatred, and only then know there is no hatred. Therefore it is said, If there is anger, then know there is anger. If there is anger, know there is anger.
This mind is created by oneself, not by one's parents. Remove evil and turn to concentration,
Do good and do not turn back.
The mind creates various actions, which lead to suffering for the body. Doing good or evil is done by the mind, and it is not done by parents, siblings, relatives, servants, or slaves.

Those who clearly understand this know that from deviance arises this dust and toil. They also do not guard the mind to prevent it from becoming confused. Therefore it is said, This is done by the mind itself, not by parents. Remove deviance and turn to concentration, and do good without turning back.
If the roof is not tightly sealed, rain will leak in. If a person does not contemplate their actions,
they will leak out lust, anger, and delusion.

Just as if a worldly person builds a palace or house that is not tightly sealed, on a rainy day there is no place that will not leak. If a person does not rectify their actions, they will leak out forms, sounds, smells, tastes, and tactile objects. If they do not contemplate the impurity of the body, they will leak out the water of the three poisons that overflow. Therefore it is said, If the roof is not tightly sealed, rain will leak in. If a person does not contemplate their actions, they will leak out lust, anger, and delusion.

All should be summarized in verses. Delusion is also like this, anger is also like this, stinginess and jealousy are also like this, arrogance is also like this, and the knot of craving is also like this.
The house is tightly sealed, and the rain does not leak in. The person himself thinks:
I am free from lust, anger, and delusion.
Just like a person who creates a palace with a tightly sealed roof, the rain does not leak in. The person himself thinks: I am free from lust, anger, and delusion, and do not leak any problems.

All should be summarized in verses. Delusion is also like this, anger is also like this, stinginess and jealousy are also like this, arrogance is also like this, and the knot of craving is also like this.
The mind is the root of phenomena, the mind is the master, the mind is the servant. If the mind thinks evil,
Then speaks and acts accordingly, suffering and evil will follow, like a cart being pulled by the yoke.
At that time, the World-Honored One told the bhiká¹£us:
From now on, recite the verse of contemplating food first, and then eat.

In the city of ÅšrÄvastÄ«, there were two beggars who went to the assembly of monks to beg for food. It happened that the holy assembly had not yet recited the verse of contemplating the food. Among them, there was a beggar who, with a mind full of jealousy, gave rise to an evil thought:
If I later obtain freedom and become the king of a country, I will use the wheel of a chariot to crush the heads of that many monks.

After reciting the verse, the beggar obtained countless amounts of food and provisions from begging. He left the road and slept with a full stomach. Hundreds of carriages passed through the area and crushed his head. He died and entered hell, suffering immeasurable pain.
The mind is the root of phenomena, the mind is the master, the mind is the servant. If the mind thinks of good,
Then in speech and action, blessings and joy will naturally follow, like a shadow following a form.
The second beggar thought to himself:
If I later obtain wealth, nobility, and become a king, I will make offerings to that many holy assemblies to prevent them from being thirsty or lacking.
At that time, the beggar obtained what he had originally intended and left to sleep under a tree. His consciousness was tranquil and still, without any chaotic thoughts.
At that time, the country had lost its ruler and there was no successor to the royal lineage. The ministers and officials gathered together to discuss:

Now that the country has no ruler and no successor, the people will likely disperse before long. The destruction of the country and the family arises from this. What strategies will you use to ensure that the country remains intact and the people do not go elsewhere?
Among them, a wise minister who was the most sagacious said to the people:

We have lost our ruler and there is no successor. We should send messengers to travel throughout the country. If there is someone with majestic appearance and sufficient blessings and rank, we should have them succeed to the throne.

They immediately sent someone to investigate and saw a person sleeping under a tree. As the sun moved, the tree's shadow did not shift, but shaded the person's body like a canopy above. The messenger saw this and went to observe:
What other extraordinary thing could there be?
This person should rightfully inherit the throne.

He then called for him to be awakened, carried in a palanquin, surrounded in front and back, and taken to the royal palace, with people shouting ten thousand years and the kingdom becoming peaceful and prosperous.
At that time, the World-Honored One, having contemplated these two meanings, then spoke this verse:
The mind is the root of phenomena, the mind is the master, the mind is the servant. If one thinks evil in the mind,
And then speaks and acts accordingly, suffering and wrongdoing will follow, like a cart wheel leaving its tracks.
The mind is the root of phenomena, the mind is the master, the mind is the servant. If one thinks good in the mind,
And then speaks and acts accordingly, blessings and joy will follow, like a shadow following a form.
Thoughts have no fixed point, they are endless and boundless. Blessings can block evil,
The awakened ones are the wise ones.

Thoughts have no fixed point, and the endlessness of non-cessation means that even though a practitioner of cultivation lets their mind wander and is unable to be focused, even if they hear the Dharma, it does not penetrate their mind.
As for the so-called endlessness of non-cessation, it refers to stealing through the body and sexual misconduct.
Therefore it is said, Thoughts have no fixed point, and the endlessness of non-cessation.

Merit can block evil, and the enlightened are the wise ones. Accumulating goodness means permanently parting with lust, anger, delusion, and arrogance. For such a person, practicing the Way is easy, and from this, blessings and virtues gradually lead to the Way.
Therefore it is said, Merit can block evil, and the enlightened are the wise ones.
Do not have impure thoughts, nor be angry with others,
If you wish to understand the Dharma, the Buddhas of the Three Times have said,
Those who eliminate arrogance, with a mind of utmost purity,
Can abandon thoughts of harm, and then hear the right Dharma.

The Buddhas, the World-Honored Ones, always use their heavenly eyes to observe events in the three periods of time, knowing that in the future world, foolish and deluded beings will be arrogant and contemptuous, not serving the Three Jewels. After my passing, the Dharma I leave behind will exist. Son of a great clan, you will transmit my sutras and admonitions, spreading them to later generations. Sentient beings who hear them will all be saved.

There was a bhiká¹£u in the Kukkuá¹­ÄrÄma in the country of VÄrÄá¹‡asÄ«, surrounded by millions in front and behind, ascending to a high seat to expound the Dharma. Those who heard the Dharma were all saved, and according to their practice and direction, each had their wishes fulfilled.
The old classics of foreign countries and the propriety of the inner Dharma, those who enter the temple to listen to the Dharma and pay homage to the Buddha should all remove their hats.

At that time, there was a king whose head originally had little hair and moreover had a wound. He also wore shoes on his feet. Relying on his noble status, he wrapped his head with a cloth and entered to listen to the sutra.
The king said:
The bhiká¹£u should expound the Dharma for me.
The bhiká¹£u said:ğŸ”½The Buddha's teachings are profound and difficult to understand. One must first remove one's hat and then listen to the Dharma.
The TathÄgata has taught that the Dharma should not be expounded to sentient beings who are wearing shoes.
Upon hearing this, the king became angry and took off his shoes, saying to the bhiká¹£u:
You should quickly expound the Dharma to satisfy my mind. If you go against my original intention, I will decapitate you.
The bhiká¹£u said to the king:
Moreover, the TathÄgata's precepts prohibit expounding the Dharma to those who cover their heads.
Upon hearing these words, the king became even more enraged and, with a majestic imperial presence, said to the bhiká¹£u:

You are trying to insult me by repeatedly turning me away. I will now bare my head and listen to you expound the Dharma. If you cannot resolve my doubts, I will take your body and divide it into three parts.
At that time, the bhiká¹£u then spoke this verse to the king:
Do not expound the Dharma to those with impure intentions, nor to angry people.
Those who wish to understand the Dharma should know that the Buddha has taught:
Those who eliminate arrogance, with a mind and thoughts extremely pure,
Able to abandon thoughts of harm, then can hear the true Dharma.

When the king heard these verses, his face was ashamed and his shadow was embarrassed. He immediately got up from his seat, prostrated with his five limbs, and repented, seeking to extinguish the faults of body, speech, and mind. He knelt for a long time with his palms joined and said to the bhiká¹£u:
I do not know if these verses were spoken by the TathÄgata's own mouth, or if the Venerable One knew my thoughts and then spoke them?
The bhiká¹£u said to the king:
These verses were spoken by the TathÄgata's own mouth. This has been a long time, not just now.
The king thought to himself:

Excellent! The great sage's three penetrating insights are unobstructed in all things. He knew that in the future there would be people like me with thoughts of anger and harm. I now deeply repent and will not create new ones.

At that time, the bhiká¹£us gradually spoke the profound Dharma to him. He immediately attained the purity of the Dharma eye on the seat, saw the Dharma, attained the Dharma, and had no fear or difficulty.
The mind has no resting place, and also does not know the Dharma, confused by worldly affairs,
without right wisdom.

The mind has no resting place, and also does not know the Dharma means the mind is like a rushing stream difficult to control and return. Water emerges from the spring source, flowing day and night. Wanting it to return to the spring source is difficult to obtain. Such a person does not know the right Dharma, and also does not know what to approach and what to abandon.
It is like a deaf person listening to the five tones, and a blind person grasping a candle. Therefore, it is said, The mind has no resting place, and also does not know the Dharma.

Those who are confused about worldly affairs and lack right wisdom are like practitioners who greedily enjoy the world, believe in deviant and inverted views, serve various gods, water, fire, the sun and moon, make sacrifices to ancestors, parents, and siblings, and hope to attain the merits of the right Dharma in their minds. It is like a person who wants to build a palace in the sky, which is very difficult.
As the sutra says:
Sacrificing by killing, one will suffer harm in return.
Therefore it is said: confused about worldly affairs, lacking right wisdom.
The thirty-six swift currents, as well as the mind's leaks,
Frequently have wrong views, based on the bonds of desire.
As for the thirty-six swift currents, there are thirty-six kinds of wrongness. There are three kinds of wrongness of the body, one in each of the three realms;
There are three kinds of extreme views, one in the desire realm, one in the form realm, and one in the formless realm;
There are twelve kinds of wrong views, four in the desire realm, four in the form realm, and four in the formless realm;
There are twelve views of stealing, four in the desire realm, four in the form realm, and four in the formless realm;

There are six precepts of stealing, two in the desire realm, two in the form realm, and two in the formless realm. Taking and combining them, there are thirty-six, causing worldly people to be confused and not see the right view. Therefore, the wise person prevents future calamities.
Therefore it is said, Thirty-six swift currents.
And the mind's outflows, the thirty-six perversions arise from the mind, overflowing in myriad ways and eventually forming wrong views. Therefore it is said, And the mind's outflows.

Repeatedly leaking wrong views, bound by sensual thoughts - this wrong view refers to the views of eternalism and annihilationism. These two wrong views are not associated with each other. The view of eternalism is not associated with the view of annihilationism, and the view of annihilationism is not associated with the view of eternalism. The views of the two people are different. Due to this wrong view, one is led to hell, hungry ghosts, or animals, and further gives rise to three thoughts: thoughts of greed, anger, and ignorance. Therefore, it is said, Repeatedly leaking wrong views, bound by sensual thoughts.
Abandoning the mind and letting loose the faculties, people follow the mind and turn back,
Destroying little by little the reputation, like a bird abandoning an empty forest.

translated: Abandoning the mind and letting loose the faculties, people turn according to the mind, there are many people in the world who delight in the five tones. If the eyes see forms and give rise to eye-consciousness, it becomes the eye-faculty. If the ears hear sounds and give rise to ear-consciousness, it becomes the ear-faculty. If the nose smells fragrances and gives rise to nose-consciousness, it becomes the nose-faculty. If the mouth knows tastes and gives rise to mouth-consciousness, it becomes the mouth-faculty. If the body knows smoothness and gives rise to body-consciousness, it becomes the body-faculty. If the mind knows dharmas and gives rise to mental consciousness, it becomes the mind-faculty. Therefore it is said, Abandoning the mind and letting loose the faculties, people turn according to the mind.

Destroying little by little one's good name, like a bird leaving an empty forest, people's faults are not considered in the future, and accumulating goodness for days is lost in an instant. They are seen and criticized by various patrons and benefactors:
We originally called you fully virtuous and pure, but who would have known that today we would see your faults?
They all despise you and do not respect you again.

It is like a flock of birds always roosting in a lush forest, greedy for the fragrance and flavor of the five fruits and flowers, when the flowers and fruits are exhausted, they each leave. The one who violates the precepts is like this, when blessings are exhausted and sins arrive, they will naturally disperse.
Therefore it is said, For a little destruction of fame, like a bird abandoning an empty forest.
Cultivate and study in solitude, be careful not to follow the traces of desire,
Do not swallow hot iron balls, wail and weep to receive the retribution.

Cultivate and study in solitude, be careful not to follow the traces of desire, always hold the mind and the practice of the mind, do not be hooked by the mind of desire, desire causes people to be confused and unable to distinguish between noble and humble, therefore it is said, cultivate and study in solitude, be careful not to follow the traces of desire.

Do not swallow hot iron balls, wailing and receiving retribution. Like being burned by fire, the pain penetrates to the bone marrow. After death, one enters hell, with myriad kinds of bitterness and suffering. Embracing a hot copper pillar, swallowing hot iron balls, wailing and receiving retribution, one does not know where to appeal. Therefore, it is said: Do not swallow hot iron balls, wailing and receiving retribution.
One should arise but does not arise, relying on strength without being diligent,
One sinks into a lowly human form, lazy and not understanding wisdom.

As for one should arise but does not arise, form refers to one who arises, a companion of the Buddha and a good friend. However, one does not create wholesome merits. Although born at a time when one encounters benefits, one's conduct is like the rain of the seven treasures filling the world. The foolish are confused and do not collect the treasures. They always receive a human form but have no foresight. Although called a human, they are of no benefit to the times.

It is the same with this. Encountering the Buddha's world, expounding the profound Dharma, foolish people grasp and are confused, unwilling to accept it. Therefore it is said, One should arise but does not arise.

Relying on strength but not being diligent, there are practitioners whose physical strength is strong and capable of receiving the teachings, yet they are lazy and not very diligent. Therefore it is said, Relying on strength but not being diligent.

Drowning oneself, with a lowly form, lazy and not understanding wisdom, drowning oneself in birth and death, not caring about the calamities of the next world, although encountering the Buddha's world, encountering good and virtuous friends and meeting with sages, unwilling to accept wisdom and discern the meaning, therefore it is said, Drowning oneself, with a lowly form, lazy and not understanding wisdom.
Distracted and correct observation, all arise from the mind,
Able to awaken to the mind's observation, the foolish mind is repeatedly confused.

As for confused observation and correct observation are all produced by the mind, the so-called confused observation is the observation of desire, the observation of anger, and the observation of ignorance. Practitioners should abandon these observations and cultivate correct observation. Correct observation and concentration surpass all other concentrations and is the most honored among them. Except for sages who have exhausted their defilements and attained non-attachment, no one can attain this concentration. Therefore, it is said, Confused observation and correct observation are all produced by the mind.

As for the observation of the mind that can awaken to the deluded mind that is confused again and again, those who study diligently should cultivate the observation of the essential path, the observation of emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness, wash away the defilements of the mind, abandon the eight worldly concerns, cultivate the pure mind, understand the various excellent characteristics, and each is empty and tranquil. The teachings and admonitions expounded are exceptionally difficult to attain. The four noble truths should be cultivated day and night as they are.

The deluded person grasps delusions and the mind is confused again and again. It is like sweet juice that the deluded person considers bitter. How could it be necessary for a sage to open their mouth and give it to them? The deluded mind is difficult to change in this way.
Therefore it is said, One who can be aware of the mind observes, the foolish mind is often disturbed.
The wise one observes thus, mindfulness is practiced exclusively,
Alas, the mind is unattached, only the Buddha can extinguish this.

The wise one observes thus, mindfulness is practiced exclusively by the practitioner, namely, the wise one expounds and speaks subtly, or expresses doubts and difficulties in advance to clarify human feelings, being in the great assembly, walking alone without companions, frequently asking the group who has doubts, I will burn away your doubts with the fire of great wisdom, observing the mind at all times without error or confusion, the student's practice takes this as the occupation, therefore it is said, The wise one observes thus, mindfulness is practiced exclusively.

Alas, the mind is unattached, only the Buddha can extinguish this, the practitioner attains concentration and samÄdhi, completely abandoning worldly defiled practices, and also abandoning worldly wholesome roots and liberated concentration.
Who is this?
Only the World-Honored Buddha can abandon it.
Therefore it is said, Alas! The mind is unattached, only the Buddha can extinguish it.
Contemplate the body as an empty jar, settle the mind as if establishing a city,
Using wisdom to battle with Mara, guard the victory and do not lose it again.
Contemplating the body as an empty jar, it is like an old and dilapidated jar, the inside and outside are not solid, although it can receive and hold, it does not last long;
This body of the four elements is also like this, always suffering from decay and destruction, unable to last long.
Just like that dilapidated [jar], it can hold both the beautiful and the ugly, but in the end it returns to destruction;
Approaching that pile of ashes;

This precarious and fragile body is also like this, it receives both the beautiful and the ugly, the good that is received adorns the body with the merit and virtue of goodness, the evil that is received abandons good conduct and defiles the mind, after death it drifts in the hills and tombs.
Therefore it is said, Contemplate the body as an empty jar.
As for Set the mind at ease as if establishing a city, the reason for establishing a city that is solid and has deep moats is simply to detest the thieves who steal the people's goods;
The mind is also like this, detesting the entanglements of the afflictions.

The city is then solid and the thieves cannot take advantage. The mind is upright and not deviant, and the afflictions cannot take advantage. Therefore it is said, Set the mind at ease as if establishing a city.

As for Use wisdom to battle with Mara, if one's skills and techniques are complete, then one can battle with the god Indra. Therefore it is said, Use wisdom to battle with Mara. Guard the victory and do not lose it again means that having conquered lust, anger, and delusion, one has no other thoughts, and always focuses the mind on what is in front, without any other thoughts. Therefore it is said, Guard the victory and do not lose it again.
To put it simply, contemplating the world is also like this.
Contemplating the body as a mass of foam, understanding the mirage,
Using wisdom to battle with Mara, guard the victory and do not lose it again.

Just as foam arises and immediately disappears, unable to last long, this body of the four elements is also like this. When gathered, it becomes a person; when scattered, it becomes qi. Originally, the four elements are obtained from one's parents. Examining their origins and ends, they are all empty and still. Examining them, one does not see their front; seeking them, one does not see their back.

Arising and ceasing, arising and being born, ceasing and ceasing, ceasing and being born, birth does not see birth, cessation does not see cessation. What ordinary people practice is upside down and they do not awaken. Therefore it is said, Contemplate the body as like foam, understand the flame and wild horse, using wisdom to battle with Mara, guard the victory and do not lose it again.
To take the essentials, contemplate the world as also like this.
Mindful of the seven factors of enlightenment, with an equal mind, without error,
One should abandon the deluded mind, delight in the acceptance of non-arising,
Exhausting defilements, being unstained, in the world attaining nirvana.

Mindful of the seven factors of awakening, with an even mind, not deviating - just as that practitioner cultivates the teachings of the factors of awakening, thinking of them day and night without letting go, therefore it is said, mindful of the seven factors of awakening, with an even mind, not deviating.

Should abandon deluded thoughts, delighting in the forbearance of non-arising - if there are sentient beings who do not give rise to a mind of kindness towards all sentient beings, then they will not reach the Way and accomplish anything;

they must abandon deluded thoughts and not be attached to the notion of form, then they will accord with the truth of the Way and delight in the forbearance of the non-arising of dharmas, with a mind of non-arising and cessation they will enter the room of the Way, therefore it is said, should abandon deluded thoughts, delighting in the forbearance of non-arising.

Those who have exhausted defilements and are without impurities, who attain final nirvana in the world, such practitioners have exhausted the defiled and accomplished the undefiled, their minds attain liberation, and they attain liberation of wisdom. In the present Dharma, they attain mastery. Such people enter the realm of the unconditioned and attain parinirvana, eternally tranquil and extinguished, never to be reborn again. Therefore it is said, Those who have exhausted defilements and are without impurities, who attain final nirvana in the world.
One should guard one's own mind, like a bull guards its tail.
There is giving to all, one will never depart from bliss.

One should guard one's own mind, like a bull guards its tail - the mind is the basis for practicing the path and creating without end. One should always restrain the mind and not let it be lost, just as that bull guards its tail day and night, fearing it might be cut off. It would rather lose its life and its wife and children, but not let a hair of its tail fall to the ground.
The bhikshu who studies the path is also like this. He would rather lose his life than violate the precepts.
Therefore it is said, One should guard one's own mind, like a cow protects its tail.

There is giving to all, one will never be separated from happiness means one must give rise to the intention to have compassion for all, regard enemies as one's own child, and Asuras, Garudas, Chandalas, Mahoragas, humans and non-humans will not be able to take advantage of them, and they will naturally receive boundless blissful rewards.
Therefore it is said, There is giving to all, one will never be separated from happiness.

Cultivating the mind of loving-kindness, one will later experience boundless bliss.

Universally loving all, having compassion for the multitude of sentient beings, when people practice loving-kindness with an impartial mind, the multitude of sentient beings is greater than the number of seeds in the earth. If reborn in the heavens, one will naturally receive blessings, with jade maidens attending from the east to the west beyond measure;

If reborn among humans, one will be of noble lineage and great wealth, born into a family of the four castes, with the seven treasures complete and without deficiency, with true and proper parents and not in a lowly state.

If one can be joyful, delighted, and not lazy, and cultivate all wholesome dharmas, one will attain a state of peace and security.

When the breath is controlled, there is joy, and body, speech, and mind are in harmony. When the mind is controlled through the breath, all illnesses are eliminated, and one no longer engages in actions of body, speech, and mind. If one practices giving, precepts, and meditation, and observes the precepts, one seeks the path of non-action. Even if one leaves home and cultivates meritorious deeds, abandoning worldly eloquence and practicing the four forms of eloquence, attaining the eight liberations, a bhiká¹£u who practices the Dharma is not apart from the sages. Therefore, it is said:
When the breath is controlled, there is joy, and body, speech, and mind are in harmony.

As for the bonds, they bind the human mind. The bonds entwine like a moth wrapping itself. When the mind is bound, one does not see the great light. Only by removing those afflictions can one illuminate and see for oneself. Therefore, it is said:
All bonds are exhausted.
There are no more afflictions.
Even if there are the sounds of the five kinds of music, they cannot delight the mind.

Even if there are the sounds of the five kinds of music, they cannot delight the mind of a person. If a practitioner's mind is in meditation, discerning the rise and fall of the five aggregates, even if the devas were to play music, wanting to make this person's mind waver, it would not happen.
Why is it so?
Because the mind sees correctly without inversion.
Therefore it is said, Even if there are the sounds of the five kinds of music, they cannot delight the mind of a person, not as good as a single correct mind, facing the Dharma of equality.

The most victorious attain good sleep, also not reckoning there is a self, it is like a practitioner not reckoning a self, attached to glory and rank, rather taking a cold stone and rolling it in the dirt, not lying down on a high bed inside a canopy with a mind bound and attached.
Therefore it is said, The most victorious attain good sleep, and do not reckon there is a self.

Those whose minds delight in meditation and do not delight in desires, when such people enter concentration their minds do not change. When entering concentration, it is tranquil and soundless. Even the same sound of a thousand carts or the same rumble of ten thousand thunderclaps cannot cause such people to depart from their correct meditation.
Why is this so?
It is because their minds attain universal kindness.
Therefore it is said, Those whose minds delight in meditation and do not delight in desires.

Those whose minds delight in meditation do not delight in desires.

Those with the most victorious joyful mind see people without self, distinguishing the four great elements that arise internally and externally, each and every one understood to be empty and not real. Therefore it is said, Those with the most victorious joyful mind also do not see a self. Those whose minds delight in meditation do not delight in desires.
All bonds are forever exhausted, like a mountain that cannot be moved,
In defilement, there is nothing to which one is attached, in anger, one does not give rise to anger.

All bonds are forever exhausted, like a mountain that cannot be moved means that for that practitioner, all bonds are forever exhausted, internally and externally pure, without flaws or impurities, the mind like a diamond that cannot be destroyed, also like Mount Tai that cannot be moved.
Why is this?

Because their grasping mind is extremely firm and solid. Dwelling in desire, they are not defiled; in misfortune, they are not afraid. Form and spirit are both empty, with nothing to which one can become attached.
Therefore it is said, All bonds are forever exhausted, like a mountain that cannot be moved, in defilement, there is nothing to which one is attached, in anger, one does not give rise to anger.
Those who have such a mind, how could they know the traces of suffering?
Without harm, without attachment, fully endowed with precepts and discipline,
In food, knowing contentment, as well as with bedding and seats,
Cultivating the mind and seeking skillful means, this is called the teachings of the buddhas.

Those who have such a mind, how can they know the traces of suffering? It is like that practitioner who refines his mind, removes all defilements and attachments, and focuses his mind on severing bonds, making daily progress without laziness. At that time, how can he know the traces of suffering?
Therefore it is said, those who have such a mind, how can they know the traces of suffering?

Harmless, unstained, and fully endowed with precepts and discipline, one does not harm oneself or others. The precepts and discipline are explained without losing the sequence. Having cultivated virtue oneself, one further uses this virtue to teach the people. Therefore it is said, harmless, unstained, and fully endowed with precepts and discipline.

Knowing contentment in food and in bedding and sitting implements, that practitioner measures his food and does not greedily overeat. He takes it to sustain his life and practice the Way. The reason for taking oil to oil the cart is to enable the heavy load to reach its destination;
It is like a person with wounds applying ointment to them. The reason for applying it is to prevent new ones from increasing and to cure the old ones.
Therefore it is said, Knowing contentment in food and in bedding and seats.

Cultivating the mind and seeking skillful means - this is what the Buddhas teach. Practitioners who collect the essential meaning, the most urgent thing in practice is the superior mind, therefore it is said, Cultivating the mind and seeking skillful means - this is what the Buddhas teach.
The practitioner observes the characteristics of the mind, discriminating and contemplating the mind,
By attaining entry into meditation, one then obtains joy and peace.

The practitioner observes the characteristics of the mind means that the practitioner knows the source of the mind, and as soon as it arises, it ceases, not allowing it to proliferate. Knowing to discriminate the good and evil of the advancing and retreating thoughts, and the events cultivated over the long eons, therefore it is said, The practitioner observes the characteristics of the mind, discriminating and contemplating the mind.
As for having attained entry into meditation, one then obtains joy and peace, why is it said that one who enters meditation?
Meditation has three meanings, and meditation is foremost, just like a king who rules the four directions. It is possible to be rich in worldly wealth but not have the wealth of the Way;

those who have meditation and concentration should be rich in the wealth of the Way and not have worldly wealth. What is meant by the wealth of the Way? The thirty-seven factors of enlightenment, meditation, samÄdhi, and the roots of various wholesome qualities.
Joy has two meanings:
there is either pure joy or impure joy.
Impure joy refers to the requisites of food, clothing, adornments, incense, flowers, cosmetics, silk, banners, and canopies. This is called impure joy.
Pure joy refers to entering meditation and concentration, being tranquil and free from activity, and having no other thoughts. This is called having pure joy.
Therefore it is said, having attained entry into meditation, one then obtains joy and peace.
Guarding the mind and adorning oneself, jealous of others and taking care of oneself,
Encountering sorrow, not suffering from suffering, the wise one abides in careful consideration.

Guarding the mind and adorning oneself, jealous of others and taking care of oneself means that the practitioner always guards against the bonds and attachments of afflictions towards forms, sounds, smells, tastes, and tactile objects, not allowing various thoughts to mix in between, and further adorns oneself with the flowers of the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment and the seven factors of awakening. Therefore it is said, guarding the mind and adorning oneself, jealous of others and taking care of oneself.

Encountering sorrow, not suffering from suffering, the wise one abides in careful consideration means that the practitioner, having attained entry into the place of fearlessness, the wise one's spirit is careful and does not move. Therefore it is said, encountering sorrow, not suffering from suffering, the wise one abides in careful consideration.
People who do not guard their minds are harmed by wrong views,
And harbor thoughts of frivolity, they go down the path to death.

As for people not guarding their minds are harmed by wrong views, practitioners do not guard against form, sound, smell, taste, touch, and dharmas. Those sentient beings who cultivate wrong paths will then enter the paths of hell, hungry ghosts, and animals;
Those who do not practice wrong views are reborn in the heavens and among humans, dwelling in the central countries and not in the eight inhospitable borderlands.
Therefore it is said, People not guarding their minds are harmed by wrong views.

As for those who harbor thoughts of frivolity go to the path of death, the reason practitioners are confused about the path is all due to being covered by the five hindrances, unable to peek at the light of wisdom. Moreover, with the five hindrances of frivolity covering them like heavy clouds, wanting to see the light of wisdom is not right. After their lives end, they will definitely go to the path of death.
Therefore it is said, Those who harbor thoughts of frivolity go to the path of death.
Therefore one should guard the mind, equally cultivating pure practices,
Right view always precedes, discerning the arising and ceasing of phenomena.

Therefore, one should guard the mind and cultivate pure conduct equally. The practitioner always guards the mind, engages in proper conduct and abandons improper conduct, knows when to walk and when to sit, and does not lose propriety in coming and going.
Therefore, it is said, Therefore, one should guard the mind and cultivate pure conduct equally.

Right view always precedes, discerning the arising and ceasing of phenomena. A person who cultivates virtue deeply knows himself, just as a household with wealth can distinguish it. A practitioner is also like this, traversing the right path of the eightfold path and controlling the four defiled and turbid [flows], holding the torch of wisdom to illuminate the dark room of the three poisons, discerning the causes and conditions of arising and ceasing, returning to a single concentration without obstruction, what difficulty is there in attaining the Way within this?
Therefore, it is said, Right view always precedes, discerning the arising and ceasing of phenomena.
